text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers on Wednesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria's caretaker cabinet started talks with the visiting International Monetary Fund mission on a new stand-by agreement.
-- Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery Neftochim said it had increased daily crude oil processing volumes to 13,000 tonnes from 9.000 tonnes.
-- The Smolyan regional court ruled Bulgaria's private Crystalbank insolvent, effective from November 28, 1995.
-- Bulgaria's interim government is expected to raise electricity and coal prices by 250 percent effective from March 1, energy ministry officials said.
-- Belgium's Solvay SA is negotiating a possible purchase of the Bulgarian state cooking salt producer in Provadia, the newspaper said without quoting sources.
Solvay bought a 60 percent stake in soda ash producer Sodi Devnya last year.
-- The interim government signed an agreement with trade unions and the Bulgarian Economic Chamber to protect incomes and secure civil peace during the mandate of the caretaker cabinet.
-- President Petar Stoyanov is expected to start today an official visit to Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary.
-- Bulgaria's budget deficit rose to 197.751 billion levs in mid-February from 165.382 billion levs at the end of January, the finance ministry said.
-- Agriculture Minister Roumen Hristov said he would propose changes in foreign trade regulations which should relieve imports of agricultural goods and raw materials.
-- Russia is ready to extend a $450 million credit to Bulgaria to complete the nuclear power plant in Belene, Russian Ambassador Leonid Kerestedjyants said.
-- Bulgaria has sealed a deal with Argentina for 130,000 tonnes of wheat, Deputy Agriculture Minister Alexander Rangelov said. -- Sofia Newsroom +359-2 981 8569
